Modules¶

MPI¶

This contents of this module will only operate correctly if called within an MPI instance.

freeqsw.MPI.load_walk(omega, filename, MPI_communicator)¶

Initialize a previously created walk using a .qsw file.

Parameters

  • omega (numpy.real64) – Interpolation paramater (\(\omega\)) in the stochastic walk master equation, must satisfy \(0 \geq \omega \leq 1\).

  • filename (str) – Target file. Must have a .qsw extention and not be currently open.

  • MPI_communicator (MPI intracommunicator) – An MPI communicator created using mpi4py.

Returns

A walk object initialized using the input systems’s H, L, sources, and sinks data. The walk.file parameter is set to the input file.

class freeqsw.MPI.walk(omega, H, L, MPI_communicator, sources=(None, None), sinks=(None, None))¶

Bases: object

The walk object handels the creation of distributed superoperators, density matrices and system propagation in an MPI environment. It also enables the saving of results and input data to a .qsw file. This object and its contianing methods will only function correctly if called within an MPI instance, as shown in the examples.

Parameters

  • omega (numpy.real64) – Interpolation paramater (\(\omega\)) in the stochastic walk master equation, must satisfy \(0 \geq \omega \leq 1\).

  • H (numpy.complex128) – The system Hamiltonian, a Hermitian matrix.

  • L (numpy.complex128) – Matrix resulting from summation of the system Lindblad operators. May be non-hermitian.

  • MPI_communicator (MPI intracommunicator) – An MPI communicator created using mpi4py.

  • sources ((numpy.int32, numpy.float64), optional) – Tuple containing a list of absorption sites and the corresponding absorption rates.

  • sinks ((numpy.int32, numpy.float64), optional) – Tuple containing a list of the emission sites and the corresponding absorption rates.

Returns

A distributed walk object containing an initialized superoperator.

File(filename, action='a')¶

Associate a .qsw file with the walk object.

If the file does not exist it is created, otherwise it is checked for consistency with the system of the walk. This file may then be used to automatically save results obtained by step() and series().

Parameters

  • filename (str) – Filename of the .qsw file, or filename of the .qsw to be created. It must end with a .qsw extension.

  • action (str) – “a”, open or create file. “w” create file, overwrite if it already exists.

construct_superoperator()¶

A distributed superoperator is constructed on walk initialization or on calling set_omega(). One-norms of the superoperator power series are calculated for using in deriving the optimal matrix exponentiation parameters when calling step() and series().

initial_state(state, name=None)¶

Sets the initial state of the density operator (\(\rho\)).

Parameters

state (np.complex128 or str) –

Possible input are:

  • A 2D-array with shape equal to H.shape or shape equal to H.shape + the number of sources and sinks.

  • A 1D-array with length equal to the diagonal of H or length equal to the diagonal of H + the number of sources and sinks. This describes an inital state with no coherences.

  • ‘sources’ - evenly distribute the initial state over all specified sources.

  • ‘even’ - evenly distribute the initial state over all sites, including an specified sources and sinks.

If needed the array will be padded to match the shape of the system operators after the addtion of absorption and emission sites (sources and sinks).

Parameters

name (str, optional) – An identifying name for the initial state, for use when saving or loading states from a .qsw file.

series(t1, t2, steps, target=None, save=False, name=None, precision=None)¶

Calculate the state of the system over the time interval t1 to t2.

Parameters

  • t1 (numpy.float64) – The starting time, must statisfy \(0 \ge t\).

  • t2 (numpy.float64) – The ending time, must statisfy \(t1 \ge t2\).

  • steps – The number of evenly spaced points in time to calculate.

  • target (int, optional) – MPI rank to receive the calculated density operator, \(\rho(t)\).

  • save (True or False, optional) – If True, save the result to an associated .qsw file.

  • name (str, optional) – Name under which to save the result, if None it defaults to ‘series + <sequential number>’.

  • precision (str, optional) – Target precision, accepts “sp” for single precision and “dp” for double precision. Defaults to “dp”.

Return rhot

If target is specified the \(\rho(t)\) is returned to the target rank.

Return type

numpy.complex128

Warning

At minimum a target must be specified, or save must be ‘True’.

set_omega(omega)¶

Re-sets the interpolation paramater (\(\omega\)) in the stochastic walk master equation. This triggers construct_superoperator().

Parameters

omega (numpy.real64) – Must satisfy \(0 \geq \omega \leq 1\).

step(t, target=None, save=False, name=None, precision=None)¶

Calculate the state of the system at time t.

Parameters

  • t (numpy.float64) – The time, must statisfy \(0 \ge t\).

  • target (int, optional) – MPI rank to receive the calculated density operator, \(\rho(t)\).

  • save (True or False, optional) – If True, save the result to an associated .qsw file.

  • name (str, optional) – Name under which to save the result, if None it defaults to ‘step + <sequential number>’.

  • precision (str, optional) – Target precision, accepts “sp” for single precision and “dp” for double precision. Defaults to “dp”.

Return rhot

If target is specified the \(\rho(t)\) is returned to the target rank.

Return type

numpy.complex128

Warning

At minimum a target must be specified, or save must be ‘True’.

operators¶

freeqsw.operators.graph(gamma, A)¶

Generate the graph Laplacian from an adjacency matrix.

Parameters

  • gamma (numpy.real64) – Scaling factor, must satisty 0 <\(\gamma\).

  • A (csr_matrix) – Graph adjacency matrix.

Return type

csr_matrix

freeqsw.operators.site_lindblads(G)¶

Generate a Lindblad operator matrix from a graph Laplacician.

Parameters

A (csr_matrix) – Graph Laplacian.

Return type

csr_matrix

freeqsw.operators.symmetrise(G)¶

Symmetrise a csr_matrix with a symmetric structure.

G is altered so as to satisfy \(G_{ij} = max(G_{ij}, G_{ji})\).

Parameters

G (csr_matrix) – Matrix to symmetrise.

Warning

The matrix must be structurally symmetric in terms of its non-zero entires.
